pull.title: configure: Use CFLAGS_FOR_BUILD when checking native compiler
pull.body:
This fixes a bug where configure would fail or disable static
ecmult tables because it wrongly checks the native compiler using
the target CFLAGS (instead of the native CFLAGS_FOR_BUILD).

Moreover, this commit adds tests to figure out whether the native
compiler supports the warning flags passed during the build, and it
contains a few minor improvements to the code that checks the native
compiler.

repo.name: secp256k1
repo.description: Optimized C library for EC operations on curve secp256k1

repo.name: secp256k1
repo.description: Optimized C library for EC operations on curve secp256k1

events.body: @greenaddress Lawrence, does this fix your issue?
@real-or-random nice! seems to work for me but I've done very basic testing. thank you!

@real-or-random I did some more testing. I found it didn't work in some cross compiling scenarios when using platform specific LDFLAGS. For example for arm it is common to add to LDFLAGS "--fix-cortex-a8" which happens to break the configure check for working_native_cc. Your PR plus something like the diff below should fix it (does for me).

```

@@ -202,6 +202,8 @@ if test x"$use_ecmult_static_precomputation" != x"no"; then
   CFLAGS="$CFLAGS_FOR_BUILD"
   SAVE_CPPFLAGS="$CPPFLAGS"
   CPPFLAGS="$CPPFLAGS_FOR_BUILD"
+  SAVE_LDFLAGS="$LDFLAGS"
+  LDFLAGS="$LDFLAGS_FOR_BUILD"
 
   warn_CFLAGS_FOR_BUILD="-Wall -Wextra -Wno-unused-function"
   saved_CFLAGS="$CFLAGS"
@@ -222,6 +224,7 @@ if test x"$use_ecmult_static_precomputation" != x"no"; then
   CFLAGS_FOR_BUILD="$CFLAGS"
   CPPFLAGS="$SAVE_CPPFLAGS"
   CFLAGS="$SAVE_CFLAGS"
+  LDFLAGS="$SAVE_LDFLAGS"
```
Oh yep, we should handle all the flags. Thanks for figuring out! I'll add a commit later.

issue.title: Ecmult precomputation fix
issue.body:
this applies a secp fix from upstream https://github.com/bitcoin-core/secp256k1/pull/584 and an additional fix to enable ecmult-static-precomputation which is otherwise automatically on by default

It then explicitly enables ecmult-static-precomputation explicitly for all the artifacts (python, java ndk and js bindings) to avoid it silently not being enabled.

events.body: Force pushed for the LDFLAGS issue
Concept ACK and utACK with those little things addressed.

events.message:
configure: Use CFLAGS_FOR_BUILD when checking native compiler

This fixes a bug where configure would fail or disable static
ecmult tables because it wrongly checks the native compiler using
the target CFLAGS (instead of the native CFLAGS_FOR_BUILD), and
similar for CPPFLAGS and LDFLAGS.

Moreover, this commit adds tests to figure out whether the native
compiler supports the warning flags passed during the build, and it
contains a few minor improvements to the code that checks the native
compiler.
Actually pass CFLAGS_FOR_BUILD and LDFLAGS_FOR_BUILD to linker

issue.title: configure: Use CFLAGS_FOR_BUILD when checking native compiler

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -168,27 +168,54 @@ else
 fi
 
 if test x"$use_ecmult_static_precomputation" != x"no"; then
+  # Temporarily switch to an environment for the native compiler
   save_cross_compiling=$cross_compiling
   cross_compiling=no
-  TEMP_CC="$CC"
+  SAVE_CC="$CC"
   CC="$CC_FOR_BUILD"
-  AC_MSG_CHECKING([native compiler: ${CC_FOR_BUILD}])
+  SAVE_CFLAGS="$CFLAGS"
+  CFLAGS="$CFLAGS_FOR_BUILD"
+  SAVE_CPPFLAGS="$CPPFLAGS"
+  CPPFLAGS="$CPPFLAGS_FOR_BUILD"
+  SAVE_LDFLAGS="$LDFLAGS"
+  LDFLAGS="$LDFLAGS_FOR_BUILD"
+
+  warn_CFLAGS_FOR_BUILD="-Wall -Wextra -Wno-unused-function"
+  saved_CFLAGS="$CFLAGS"
+  CFLAGS="$CFLAGS $warn_CFLAGS_FOR_BUILD"
+  AC_MSG_CHECKING([if native ${CC_FOR_BUILD} supports ${warn_CFLAGS_FOR_BUILD}])
+  AC_COMPILE_IFELSE([AC_LANG_SOURCE([[char foo;]])],
+      [ AC_MSG_RESULT([yes]) ],
+      [ AC_MSG_RESULT([no])
+        CFLAGS="$saved_CFLAGS"
+      ])
+
+  AC_MSG_CHECKING([for working native compiler: ${CC_FOR_BUILD}])
   AC_RUN_IFELSE(
-    [AC_LANG_PROGRAM([], [return 0])],
+    [AC_LANG_PROGRAM([], [])],
comments.body:
IIRC The "return 0" silences a warning, which can have an effect with -Werror.

Maybe I have that backwards, what was the reason for this change?

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -168,27 +168,54 @@ else
 fi
 
 if test x"$use_ecmult_static_precomputation" != x"no"; then
+  # Temporarily switch to an environment for the native compiler
   save_cross_compiling=$cross_compiling
   cross_compiling=no
-  TEMP_CC="$CC"
+  SAVE_CC="$CC"
   CC="$CC_FOR_BUILD"
-  AC_MSG_CHECKING([native compiler: ${CC_FOR_BUILD}])
+  SAVE_CFLAGS="$CFLAGS"
+  CFLAGS="$CFLAGS_FOR_BUILD"
+  SAVE_CPPFLAGS="$CPPFLAGS"
+  CPPFLAGS="$CPPFLAGS_FOR_BUILD"
+  SAVE_LDFLAGS="$LDFLAGS"
+  LDFLAGS="$LDFLAGS_FOR_BUILD"
comments.body:
Not a problem with this PR, but this points out that LDFLAGS_FOR_BUILD is currently unused. And while we're fixing that, may as well add CFLAGS_FOR_BUILD to the link-line as well, as would be expected:
```patch
diff --git a/Makefile.am b/Makefile.am
index bfa3f46..4f89b78 100644
--- a/Makefile.am
+++ b/Makefile.am
@@ -115,7 +115,7 @@ gen_%.o: src/gen_%.c
        $(CC_FOR_BUILD) $(CPPFLAGS_FOR_BUILD) $(CFLAGS_FOR_BUILD) -c $< -o $@

 $(gen_context_BIN): $(gen_context_OBJECTS)
-       $(CC_FOR_BUILD) $^ -o $@
+       $(CC_FOR_BUILD) $(CFLAGS_FOR_BUILD) $(LDFLAGS_FOR_BUILD) $^ -o $@

 $(libsecp256k1_la_OBJECTS): $(SECP256K1_ECMULT_STATIC_CONTEXT_HEADER_INT)
 $(tests_OBJECTS): $(SECP256K1_ECMULT_STATIC_CONTEXT_HEADER_INT)
```
(I'm working on a heavily modified branch, that may be different in master but you get the idea.)

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -168,27 +168,54 @@ else
 fi
 
 if test x"$use_ecmult_static_precomputation" != x"no"; then
+  # Temporarily switch to an environment for the native compiler
   save_cross_compiling=$cross_compiling
   cross_compiling=no
-  TEMP_CC="$CC"
+  SAVE_CC="$CC"
   CC="$CC_FOR_BUILD"
-  AC_MSG_CHECKING([native compiler: ${CC_FOR_BUILD}])
+  SAVE_CFLAGS="$CFLAGS"
+  CFLAGS="$CFLAGS_FOR_BUILD"
+  SAVE_CPPFLAGS="$CPPFLAGS"
+  CPPFLAGS="$CPPFLAGS_FOR_BUILD"
+  SAVE_LDFLAGS="$LDFLAGS"
+  LDFLAGS="$LDFLAGS_FOR_BUILD"
+
+  warn_CFLAGS_FOR_BUILD="-Wall -Wextra -Wno-unused-function"
+  saved_CFLAGS="$CFLAGS"
+  CFLAGS="$CFLAGS $warn_CFLAGS_FOR_BUILD"
+  AC_MSG_CHECKING([if native ${CC_FOR_BUILD} supports ${warn_CFLAGS_FOR_BUILD}])
+  AC_COMPILE_IFELSE([AC_LANG_SOURCE([[char foo;]])],
+      [ AC_MSG_RESULT([yes]) ],
+      [ AC_MSG_RESULT([no])
+        CFLAGS="$saved_CFLAGS"
+      ])
+
+  AC_MSG_CHECKING([for working native compiler: ${CC_FOR_BUILD}])
   AC_RUN_IFELSE(
-    [AC_LANG_PROGRAM([], [return 0])],
+    [AC_LANG_PROGRAM([], [])],
     [working_native_cc=yes],
     [working_native_cc=no],[dnl])
-  CC="$TEMP_CC"
+
+  CFLAGS_FOR_BUILD="$CFLAGS"
+
+  # Restore the environment
   cross_compiling=$save_cross_compiling
+  CC="$SAVE_CC"
+  CFLAGS="$SAVE_CFLAGS"
+  CPPFLAGS="$SAVE_CPPFLAGS"
+  LDFLAGS="$SAVE_LDFLAGS"
 
   if test x"$working_native_cc" = x"no"; then
+    AC_MSG_RESULT([no])
     set_precomp=no
+    m4_define([please_set_for_build], [Please set CC_FOR_BUILD and/or CFLAGS_FOR_BUILD, CPPFLAGS_FOR_BUILD, and LDFLAGS_FOR_BUILD.])
comments.body: Nit: CC_FOR_BUILD, CFLAGS_FOR_BUILD, CPPFLAGS_FOR_BUILD, and/or LDFLAGS_FOR_BUILD.

-    [AC_LANG_PROGRAM([], [return 0])],

comments.body: This change is rather cosmetic. We're using `AC_LANG_PROGRAM` here, which adds already `return 0` according to  https://www.gnu.org/software/autoconf/manual/autoconf-2.65/html_node/Generating-Sources.html. So previously we had two returns.
